details.description: Pension Credit is extra money for pensioners to bring your weekly income up to a minimum amount -  what you'll get, apply, eligibility

parts.title: Overview
parts.body:
Pension Credit is an income related benefit made up of 2 parts - Guarantee Credit and Savings Credit.

Guarantee Credit tops up your weekly income if it’s below £142.70 (single people) or £217.90 (couples).

Savings Credit is an extra payment for people who have saved some money towards their retirement, eg a pension.

You don’t pay tax on Pension Credit.

Use the Pension Credit calculator to work out how much you might get.

parts.title: What you'll get
parts.body:
Your circumstances Guarantee Credit per week Savings Credit per week
Single people Top up to £142.70 Up to £18.54
Couples Top up to £217.90 Up to £23.73

If you’re a carer, severely disabled or have certain housing costs, these amounts might be more.

Use the Pension Credit calculator to work out how much you might get.

You might be eligible for other benefits when you get Pension Credit - check the benefits adviser.

How you’re paid

All benefits, pensions and allowances are paid into an account, eg a bank account.

parts.title: Eligibility
parts.body:
To qualify for Guarantee Credit:

  • you must live in Great Britain
  • you or your partner must have reached Pension Credit qualifying age

The qualifying age for Pension Credit is gradually going up to 66 in line with the increase in the State Pension age for women to 65 and the further increase to 66 for men and women.

Download ‘Pension Credit and when you could get it’ (PDF, 149KB)

To qualify for the extra Savings Credit you or your partner must be 65 or over.

You don’t have to be married or in a civil partnership to count as a couple.

If you move abroad permanently you can’t get Pension Credit.

Working out your income

When you apply your income is worked out. This includes:

  • State Pension (basic and additional)
  • other pensions
  • most social security benefits, eg Carer’s Allowance
  • savings, investments over £10,000 - for these £1 is counted for every £500 or part £500
  • earnings

The following isn’t included when your income is worked out:

  • Attendance Allowance
  • Christmas Bonus 
  • Disability Living Allowance
  • Housing Benefit
  • Council Tax Benefit

If you’re registered for Self Assessment, you must tell The Pension Service how much Income Tax you expect to pay for the current tax year - this affects how much Pension Credit you’ll get.

parts.title: How to claim
parts.body:
You can apply for Pension Credit:

  • by post - send it to your local pension centre
  • by phone

You can download form PC1F, fill in the boxes and print it out, or you can download form PC1, print it out and write in the boxes.

Download ‘Pension Credit application form PC1F’ (PDF, 634KB)

Download ‘Pension Credit application form PC1’ (PDF, 945KB)

Pension Credit claims line
Telephone: 0800 99 1234
Textphone: 0800 169 0133
Monday to Friday, 8am to 6pm

What you need to claim

You will need:

  • your National Insurance number
  • information about your income, savings and investments
  • your bank account details

The earliest you can start your application is 4 months before you reach Pension Credit qualifying age.

You can claim any time after you reach Pension Credit qualifying age but your claim can only be backdated for 3 months.

If your circumstances change

Phone the helpline if your circumstances change as this can affect how much you get. For example, if you income or capital goes up or down.

Pension Service helpline
Telephone: 0845 60 60 265
Textphone: 0800 169 0133
Monday to Friday, 8am to 6pm

Appeal a decision

You can appeal a decision about your Pension Credit if you’re unhappy with it.

Download ‘Leaflet GL24, Appeal against a benefit decision’ (PDF, 4915KB)
